childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1959-1971

Growing up in the early 1960s meant a world of tactile textures. The smell of a grandmother's kitchen—Crisco in a cast-iron skillet, Maxwell House percolating on the counter, Wonder Bread in the breadbox. The crackle of the transistor radio playing 'Venus' by Frankie Avalon. The satisfying click of Lincoln Logs snapping together. Childhood had a weight to it that children today will never understand—everything was built to last, because throwing things away was still considered wasteful.

On March 9, 1959, three months before this cohort was born, a plastic doll named Barbie debuted at the American Toy Fair in New York. She cost $3. By their fifth birthday, she'd be everywhere—Barbie Dream Houses, Barbie clothes, Barbie as a cultural argument about what girls should aspire to be. They grew up alongside her, though whether she shaped them or they shaped her is a question nobody's quite settled.

At four, they watched their parents cry in front of the television. They didn't understand it—they were four—but they understood that something terrible had happened, that the world had broken in some way the adults couldn't explain. Dallas taught them that lesson before they had words for it. Five years later, Martin Luther King Jr. and Bobby Kennedy were both gunned down within two months. By the time they were nine, they'd absorbed the lesson that America killed its dreamers.

Saturday mornings belonged to Rocky and Bullwinkle, with their jokes they wouldn't understand for another decade. The Flintstones on Friday nights—a cartoon for grown-ups that kids watched anyway. Sunday evenings meant The Wonderful World of Disney and the peacock spreading its feathers on NBC (if they were lucky enough to have a color set). They watched The Twilight Zone when their parents let them, scared and thrilled in equal measure, Rod Serling's cigarette smoke curling through dimensions unknown.

They built model rockets and slot car tracks. They collected baseball cards and stuck them in their bicycle spokes. They played Kick the Can until the streetlights came on. TV dinners came on folding trays, the aluminum compartments keeping Salisbury steak separate from mashed potatoes. Tang sat in the cabinet—the drink the astronauts drank, orange powder that made them part of the space age. They were ten years old when Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon, and they watched it live, in their living room, believing anything was possible.

generational_identity.html:
The Boomer Generation

Baby Boomer. The label was coined by a newspaper columnist in 1963, when this cohort was four years old, to describe the demographic explosion that followed World War II. Eighteen million GIs came home, started families, and this generation—76 million strong—was the result. They're the largest generation in American history, at least until Millennials eventually edged past them. They've dominated every decade they've lived through by sheer force of numbers.

At four, President Kennedy was shot in Dallas. November 22, 1963. They were in preschool, maybe kindergarten. They probably don't remember the specific moment, but they remember the aftermath—adults weeping openly, the television on for days, the funeral procession. This is this generation's defining rupture, the moment that split the American century in two. The optimism of Camelot died in that motorcade.

Born in 1959, they're what demographers call 'Late Boomers' or 'Generation Jones'—named for the jones, the longing, for the opportunities their older siblings seemed to have. They weren't at Woodstock—they were ten years old in August 1969, probably watching the news coverage with a mix of fascination and confusion. They didn't burn their draft card because the draft ended when they were fourteen. They inherited the counterculture second-hand: the music, the fashion, the attitude, but not the tear gas at the '68 Democratic Convention.

This generation gets blamed for pulling the ladder up behind them. For defunding public universities after they graduated from them. For voting for tax cuts that starved the programs that built them. For treating housing as investment rather than shelter. Whether that's fair criticism or generational scapegoating depends on the day and who's doing the math. What's undeniable is that the path they walked has been paved over, and pointing to it as if it's still there doesn't help their children, who are still renting in their forties.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, this cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Another rupture, another before-and-after, another moment when the world cracked open and revealed something darker underneath.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

February 3, 1959. Four months before this generation was born, Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and the Big Bopper died in a plane crash near Clear Lake, Iowa. Don McLean would later call it 'the day the music died,' but rock and roll was just getting started. Elvis was in the Army, stationed in Germany. Berry Gordy was about to found Motown Records in a Detroit house he called Hitsville USA. The music that would define their childhood was being born alongside them.

Ben-Hur swept the Oscars their birth year—eleven wins, a record that would stand for decades. Bonanza premiered on NBC, launching the golden age of TV westerns. The Twilight Zone debuted on CBS, Rod Serling inviting America into dimensions of imagination. These weren't their shows yet—they were babies—but they'd be in syndication throughout their childhood, absorbed through endless reruns.

At five, they watched the Beatles on The Ed Sullivan Show. February 9, 1964. Seventy-three million Americans tuned in. Their parents didn't understand why the girls were screaming. They might not have either, but they understood something was happening. The British Invasion had landed. By the time they were seven, they knew every word to 'I Want to Hold Their Hand' and 'She Loves this generation.' By ten, they were ready for Sgt. Pepper's.

Their teenage years coincided with rock's greatest evolution. At twelve, Led Zeppelin released their debut album. At thirteen, they heard 'Stairway to Heaven' for the first time. At fourteen, Dark Side of the Moon. They bought vinyl at the record store—actual records, with gatefold covers they studied like sacred texts. They argued about whether the Stones were better than the Beatles, whether Zeppelin was heavier than Sabbath, whether Hendrix was from this planet at all.

Television meant Gilligan's Island, The Beverly Hillbillies, and Bewitched. It meant laughing at Gomer Pyle and learning about space from Star Trek. It meant watching Vietnam on the evening news, body counts delivered between commercials for Chevrolet. By the time M*A*S*H premiered when they were thirteen, the irony of a show about Korea that was really about Vietnam wasn't lost on them.

At seventeen, they watched Saturday Night Live's first episode—'Live from New York!' At twenty, they survived the disco era (Saturday Night Fever, the Bee Gees, platform shoes they'd later deny owning). At twenty-two, MTV launched with 'Video Killed the Radio Star.' They were young enough to understand it, old enough to remember when music was something they listened to rather than watched.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1959, Jack Kilby demonstrated the first integrated circuit at Texas Instruments—a tiny chip that would eventually put more computing power in a pocket than existed on the entire planet in 1959. But that was decades away. In their childhood, 'computer' meant a room-sized machine fed by punch cards, operated by men in white lab coats at IBM and Bell Labs. Science fiction, not daily life.

Their first television was black-and-white, probably a console that sat in the living room like furniture. They remember when their family got their first color set—maybe 1965, maybe later—and how strange The Wonderful World of Disney looked when the peacock actually had colors. The test pattern at the end of the broadcast day. The satisfying clunk of the rotary channel dial. Rabbit ears that needed constant adjustment.

At ten, they watched men walk on the moon. July 20, 1969. The grainy footage, Armstrong's crackly voice, the impossible made real in their living room. Technology had delivered on its promise. The future was arriving on schedule. They believed, in a way their grandchildren never quite will, that progress was linear and inevitable.

At sixteen, the Altair 8800 appeared—the first personal computer for hobbyists, sold as a kit for $439. They probably didn't notice. At twenty, the Apple II brought home computing to actual humans who didn't speak assembly language. At twenty-two, IBM released its PC, and suddenly offices had screens on every desk. They were young enough to adapt, old enough to remember when typewriters were state of the art.

They were thirty-five when the World Wide Web went public. Dial-up modems that screamed like fax machines. AOL CDs in every mailbox. 'this generation've Got Mail' as a cultural event. Email felt revolutionary—instant communication across oceans! By forty, they'd learned to search on Google. By forty-eight, Facebook existed. By fifty, they held an iPhone and the entire sum of human knowledge fit in their palm.

This generation has watched technology advance more in their lifetime than in all previous human history combined. They've kept pace, more or less. But their relationship with it remains practical rather than native. They can still read a paper map, balance a checkbook by hand, remember phone numbers without a contact list. These skills feel increasingly quaint, but they work when the power goes out.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

At four, Dallas. The rupture that defines this generation happened while they were in preschool—the details live in the Generational Identity section. Here, what matters is that it launched a decade of violence against leaders that would shape their entire understanding of American power. Their first lesson in how quickly everything can change.

They were three during the Cuban Missile Crisis—October 1962, thirteen days when nuclear annihilation felt imminent. They don't remember it, but the adults around them did. The fallout shelter signs, the duck-and-cover drills, the maps showing missile range circles centered on their city. The Cold War wasn't abstract for their parents. It was existential. They grew up in the shadow of the mushroom cloud.

At nine, Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis. Two months later, Bobby Kennedy was shot in a Los Angeles hotel kitchen. They were old enough now to understand. Old enough to watch the funeral trains on television. Old enough to absorb the lesson that America killed its dreamers. At ten, Neil Armstrong walked on the moon—the promise kept, proof that the future was real. Six months later, Altamont ended the Summer of Love's fantasy with a stabbing caught on film. The sixties gave them whiplash.

Vietnam was background noise throughout their childhood—body counts on the evening news, protests on college campuses their older siblings might have attended. 58,220 Americans died in that war. They were sixteen when Saigon fell. April 30, 1975. Helicopters on embassy rooftops, desperate evacuations, the longest war in American history ending not with victory but with humiliation. Their generation's older brothers came home changed, or didn't come home at all.

Watergate unfolded during their high school years. They watched a president lie on national television, then resign in disgrace. 'I am not a crook' became a punchline. At fifteen, they'd learned that authority figures lied, that institutions were corrupt, that the system would protect itself before it protected them. This was their political education.

At thirty, the Berlin Wall fell—November 1989, crowds with sledgehammers, champagne in the streets. The Cold War that had defined their entire life simply ended. At {{AGE_AT_911}}, they watched the Twin Towers fall on live television, and a different kind of war began. At forty-nine, the financial system collapsed, retirement accounts evaporating, banks too big to fail failing anyway. History hasn't stopped. It's just started moving faster than they can process.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

The job market of 1981 offered a challenging entry point. Unemployment hit 10.8% in late 1982, the highest since the Great Depression. The post-war boom their older siblings rode was over. Stagflation—that impossible combination of high unemployment and high inflation—had rewritten the rules. Gas lines stretched around blocks. Interest rates hit 20%. The easy jobs their cousins found in 1970 had evaporated by the time they went looking.

This generation invented careerism as a lifestyle. They read 'Dress for Success' and bought the power suits. They networked before networking was a verb. They understood that the organization man was dead—killed by layoffs, downsizing, the first wave of 'restructuring' that would become a permanent condition. They were supposed to be their own brand, chart their own path. Which really meant they were on their own when things went wrong.

The deal changed while they were mid-career. They started with the expectation of a pension—defined benefit, employer-funded, retirement as a promise. By the late '80s, 401(k)s had replaced them—defined contribution, employee-funded, retirement as a gamble. The risk shifted from corporations to them, dressed up as 'flexibility' and 'control.' They adapted because they had to. Their kids never had the pension option at all.

If they're women, their career arc was complicated by expectations their daughters can barely imagine. The glass ceiling wasn't a metaphor—it was policy, culture, law. They were told they could have it all: career, family, fulfillment. What they meant was they could do it all, perfectly, while being paid less and promoted slower. Whatever they achieved, they achieved against headwinds the official narrative pretended didn't exist. Sandra Day O'Connor joined the Supreme Court when they were twenty-two. Progress was possible. It was just exhausting.

They've probably retired by now, or they're close. Social Security is real for them—they'll actually collect it, unlike their children who view it as a theoretical construct that might not survive their lifetimes. Medicare will cover their healthcare. If they're lucky, they have a paid-off house that appreciated 400% while they weren't looking. This generation got the last reliable version of American retirement. They didn't design the system—they just participated in it, followed the rules as they existed, built a life on a foundation that was later demolished for those who followed.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis hit—and retirement plans evaporated overnight. The market recovered eventually. The lesson didn't fade.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

The generation that came of age when getting someone's phone number meant actually calling their house. Rotary dial, wait for the connection, hope their father didn't answer. The courage required to make that call—sitting in the kitchen where everyone could hear, stretching the cord as far as it would reach for the illusion of privacy. There was no texting, no DMs, no way to communicate that didn't involve a voice and immediate vulnerability.

This cohort came of age during the sexual revolution, which sounds more liberating than it often was. The Pill became widely available when they were teenagers. Premarital sex stopped being automatically scandalous. But nobody quite knew what the new rules were—their parents' courtship scripts were obsolete, and nothing had replaced them yet. They made it up as they went along, which was exciting and terrifying in roughly equal measure.

They probably married younger than their children will—mid-twenties was standard, late twenties raised eyebrows. Divorce rates peaked in the 1980s, when they were in their twenties; this generation normalized ending marriages that didn't work, which horrified their parents and liberated them. Whether they're on their first spouse or their third, they're part of a pattern their generation created: the belief that personal fulfillment matters more than institutional obligation.

Their friendships were built in person—neighbors, coworkers, the parents of their children's friends. They remember people's birthdays without Facebook reminders. They have phone numbers memorized from the 1970s. They stayed in touch with Christmas cards and occasional long-distance calls that cost real money by the minute. The people they've known for forty years know them in ways that two hundred Instagram followers never will.

Their children communicate in ways that feel alien. They text instead of calling. They have 'friends' they've never met. They share intimate details with strangers on the internet and call them once a month if they're lucky. This generation worries about them, and they think their parents don't understand. Both of them are right. The chasm between how they built relationships and how their children build theirs is wider than technology—it's a different understanding of what connection means.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The economic landscape for those entering adulthood was shaped by parents who survived the Great Depression. They saved obsessively, distrusted banks with a wariness born of watching them fail. This generation inherited some of that caution—they remember the lectures about waste, the insistence on finishing everything on their plate—but prosperity made it feel obsolete. Credit cards arrived. Mortgages were cheap. The stock market only went up. Why hoard when abundance felt permanent?

In 1985, when this cohort was twenty-six, the median home price was about $75,000—roughly three times the median income. A house was something they bought in their twenties, not something they dreamed about in their forties. They bought one. It appreciated 400% while they slept. The wealth they accumulated wasn't because they were smarter than their children. It was because they were earlier.

This generation has watched the market boom and crash, boom and crash. Black Monday in 1987—they were twenty-eight, watching the Dow drop 22% in a single day. The dot-com bubble when they were forty-one. The 2008 collapse when they were forty-nine, retirement accounts evaporating just as they were starting to count on them. Each time, they were told the fundamentals were sound. Each time, they weren't. They learned that the market is a casino with better PR, but they kept playing because mattresses don't compound.

Their biggest financial anxiety now is longevity risk—outliving their savings. They planned for retirement at 65, but they might live to 90. Healthcare costs compound. The math they did at forty doesn't work at seventy. Nobody told them to plan for three decades of not working.

The 401(k) replaced the pension during their career—all the risk transferred to them, all the responsibility for investing correctly, all the anxiety about whether their spreadsheets were right. Their parents got defined benefits and never worried about outliving their money. They got flexibility, control, and chronic uncertainty.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

Here's the thing nobody wants to say: this generation believes their success was entirely earned. It was partly earned—they worked hard, made sacrifices, showed up when showing up mattered. But it was also partly structural. They came of age when unions were strong, when college cost a summer job, when one income could support a family of four in a house with a yard. Those conditions weren't their achievement. They were their context. And they're gone.

'Just walk in and ask for the manager.' 'Pound the pavement.' 'A firm handshake and eye contact.' This is the advice they give, because it's what worked for them. But it describes a world that no longer exists. Resumes go into digital voids. Algorithms screen candidates before humans see them. Entry-level positions require three years of experience. The path they walked has been paved over, and pointing to it as if it's still there doesn't help anyone.

Their relationship with technology often slides from skepticism into dismissal. They didn't grow up online, so online life can feel trivial—all that sharing, all that posting, all that performing for strangers. But for younger generations, the internet is where careers happen, where movements organize, where identity gets negotiated in real time. Dismissing it as 'not real life' dismisses them. And they notice.

This cohort was raised to believe in institutions—government, corporations, the church, marriage—that have since proven less trustworthy than advertised. Their instinct is to reform them, to work within the system, to trust that incremental change will eventually deliver justice. Younger generations, having watched those institutions fail repeatedly, are more inclined to burn it all down and build something new. Both approaches have merit. Neither has a monopoly on wisdom. But the urgency gap between them is real, and it's growing.

The hardest blind spot: the planet. This generation got Earth at a particular moment—post-war abundance, cheap energy, seemingly infinite growth. The environmental costs were hidden or deferred. Climate change is happening now, with consequences their grandchildren will pay. They didn't cause it alone, but they benefited from the system that caused it, and they voted for leaders who denied it was happening while the evidence piled up. This isn't entirely their fault. But pretending it's not partially their responsibility doesn't hold up anymore.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

20s (1979-1989): The typical trajectory for someone born in 1959 meant entering adulthood during economic turbulence—gas lines, stagflation, the worst recession since the Depression. Interest rates hit 20%. The easy paths their older cousins found were crowded or closed. Reagan promised morning in America, but the sun rose unevenly. They hustled, networked, bought the power suits. They probably got married in this decade—mid-twenties was standard. They definitely bought a house, because houses were still affordable on a middle-class salary. This was the decade where they laid the foundation for everything that came after.

30s (1989-1999): The Berlin Wall fell. The Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War that had defined their entire life simply ended, and suddenly the future felt wide open. The economy boomed—dot-com money flowing, tech stocks soaring, irrational exuberance everywhere. They advanced in their career, reached middle management or better, watched their house appreciate faster than their salary. Their kids were in school. Their parents were still healthy. This was the sweet spot: old enough to have authority, young enough to have energy. The '90s felt like they might last forever.

40s (1999-2009): Y2K was a fizzle. September 11 was not. They were forty-two when the towers fell, old enough to understand the world had shifted, to feel the whiplash of 'before' and 'after' for the second time in their life. The Iraq War. The housing bubble inflating, then exploding. The financial crisis that nearly collapsed the global economy when they were forty-nine—retirement accounts evaporating just as they were starting to count on them. Their kids became teenagers, then adults. Their parents started needing help. The future felt less certain than it had a decade earlier.

50s (2009-2019): Recovery, slow and uneven. They helped their kids through college, paid tuition that had tripled since they attended, watched them graduate into a job market that treated them like expendable labor. Their parents needed more help, then passed away—the generation that survived the Depression and won the war, gone. The sandwich generation squeeze was real: responsibilities on both ends, support for neither. They started thinking seriously about retirement, about legacy, about what kind of world they were leaving behind.

60s (2019-2029): They're in this decade now. COVID reshaped their final working years or early retirement—remote work, isolation, the strange gift of time to think about what matters. Grandchildren, if they have them, are growing up in a world they barely recognize: climate anxiety, school shooting drills, politics as tribal warfare. They're trying to stay relevant while accepting that relevance might not be the point anymore. Their health is the variable that determines everything else.

70s and beyond (2029+): The actuarial tables give them another decade of good years, maybe more with luck and medicine. Healthcare will be their largest expense. Mobility, cognition, independence—these will narrow, gradually or suddenly. They'll tell stories about the world before the internet, before smartphones, before everything was connected and surveilled. Whether anyone listens depends on relationships they built decades ago. The finish line is visible now. What they leave behind—money, memories, lessons—is largely determined. What remains is how they spend what's left.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in America the same year—part of a 76 million generation. They've dominated every decade they've lived through by sheer demographic weight: the economy, politics, culture, all of it shaped by their numbers.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They came of age during Depression and war, learned to keep their heads down, follow rules, build quietly. Boomers came of age during abundance and questioned everything. The Silent Generation trusted institutions because institutions had saved them. Boomers distrusted institutions because they'd seen them lie about Vietnam, Watergate, everything. The Silent Generation saved; Boomers spent. The Silent Generation were grateful for stability; Boomers demanded authenticity. The stereotypes flatten the reality, but the arc is clear: the Silent Generation built the system, Boomers inherited it, and Boomers are leaving it different than they found it.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): The forgotten middle child, squeezed between Boomer demographic dominance and the Millennial surge that followed. They grew up as latchkey kids, raising themselves while Boomers climbed corporate ladders. They're cynical in ways Boomers find tiresome, realistic in ways Boomers find defeatist. They got the leftovers of the prosperity Boomers enjoyed—the jobs Boomers didn't take, the housing market after Boomers had bought in. They expect less because they received less. They haven't forgiven Boomers for it, and they're not entirely wrong.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): This generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. Boomers bought houses in their twenties; Millennials are renting in their forties. Boomers had pensions; Millennials have student loans. Boomers graduated into opportunity; Millennials graduated into the Great Recession. Millennials aren't bitter so much as exhausted. The system that worked for Boomers broke before Millennials could use it, and they've spent their adult lives being blamed for not making it work anyway.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): They're from different planets. Gen Z has never known a world without smartphones, without school shooting drills, without climate crisis as background radiation. They're anxious in ways that seem excessive until this generation remember what they've absorbed since childhood. They don't expect Social Security to exist when they're sixty-five. They don't expect the planet to be habitable when they're Boomers' age. They might be right about both.

Their life expectancy at birth was about 70 years. Modern medicine extended that—they can reasonably expect 80, maybe longer with luck and good genes. They've outlived more assumptions than any generation before them. The world they were born into—rotary phones, black-and-white TV, segregated lunch counters, the Soviet threat—has vanished. The world they'll leave behind—AI, climate emergency, smartphones in every pocket—is unrecognizable. That's the Boomer experience: everything changed, including them.

year_events: Fidel Castro took power in Cuba
Buddy Holly died in a plane crash
